Virtuoso Layout Suite XL: Basic Editing User Guide
Product Version ICADVM20.1, October 2020

B

Environment Variables

Environment Variable Functions

This appendix contains the Virtuoso® Layout Suite L layout editor and graphics editor environment variable names, descriptions, types, and values. Graphic environment variables control the characteristics of the window display and layout environment variables control how various layout editor commands work. Many graphic environment variables have duplicate layout environment variables. In these cases, the layout variable supersedes the graphic variable unless the graphic variable is stored in the cellview. You can set both types of environment variables: graphic and layout.

Only the environment variables documented in this chapter are supported for public use. All other Layout editor environment variables, regardless of their name or prefix, and undocumented aspects of the environment variables described below, are private and are subject to change at any time.

Checking the Value of an Environment Variable

To determine the current value of an environment variable,

  • Type in the CIW
    envGetVal( "layout" "variable_name" )
    or
    envGetVal( "graphic" "variable_name" )
    For example
    envGetVal( "layout" "accessEdgesOn" )
    or
    envGetVal( "graphic" "accessEdgesOn" )

How the System Evaluates Environment Variables

The system looks for the value of an environment variable as follows:

  1. If no layout license is available the system looks for the system-defined default settings in the following file:
    install_dir/etc/tools/graphic/.cdsenv
  2. If a layout license is available the system looks for the system-defined default settings in the following file:
    install_dir/etc/tools/layout/.cdsenv
  3. Then the system loads any values in the local .cdsenv file in your home directory,
    ~/.cdsenv
    The layout variables supersede any matching graphic variables, and environment variables defined in your .cdsenv supersede any default values in the graphic or layout .cdsenv.
There is a precedence of window settings which might override environment variable settings. The order in which the settings are read is: cellview properties, library properties, technology library properties, and lastly, environment variable values. Therefore, any override window properties stamped on a cellview will take precedence over a setting in the .cdsenv file.

Graphic Environment Variables

Graphic environment variables control the window display. These variables can be stored in the cellview or the .cdsenv file. There are several ways to change the default settings of graphic environment variables:

  • Set the variable in the Display Options Form.
    If you want to retain these settings for future sessions, save the settings using the Save button in the Options – Save Defaults form in the CIW.
  • Copy the variables you want to change from the default .cdsenv file to the .cdsenv file in your home directory.
    It is there that you edit the default value. The default file is
    your_install_dir/tools/dfII/samples/.cdsenv

    Do not use the .cdsenv system files located in the following directory:
    your_install_dir/tools/dfII/etc/tools/*/.cdsenv
    These files contain system default values for all applications and have extra arguments that do not work in your environment.
  • Set the variable in the CIW using
    envSetVal("graphic" "name" type value)
    For example:
    envSetVal("graphic" "iconsOn" 'boolean t)
    To determine the current value of a graphic environment variable, type in the CIW
    envGetVal("graphic" "name")
    For example:
    envGetVal("graphic" "iconsOn")

Layout Editor Environment Variables

Layout environment variables control how various layout editor commands work. There are several ways to change the default settings of layout environment variables:

  • Set the variable in the Layout Editor Options Form. If you want to retain these settings for future sessions, save the settings in the Save Defaults form in the Options menu in the CIW.
  • Include the environment variables in your .cdsenv file in your home directory. The default file is
    your_install_dir/tools/dfII/samples/.cdsenv
  • Include the envSetVal() function in your .cdsinit file.
  • Include the envSetVal() function in any other SKILL file you load.
  • Type the envSetVal() function in the CIW.

For example, to set the gravityOn variable, type the following in the CIW or include it in a file:

envSetVal("layout" "gravityOn" 't)

To determine the current value of any layout editor environment variable, type the envGetVal() function in the CIW as follows:

envGetVal("layout" "variable_name")

Copying Environment Variables from the Samples Directory to ~/.cdsenv

Do not copy lines from the graphic/.cdsenv or layout/.cdsenv files to the .cdsenv file in your home directory. The file formats are slightly different, so the lines that result from copying do not work.

Copy the default environment variables from the sample .cdsenv file located at:

your_install_dir/tools/dfII/samples/.cdsenv

Copy the variables you want to change from the sample .cdsenv file to the .cdsenv file in your home directory, and edit the default values in your .cdsenv file.

Setting the variables in the .cdsenv file in your home directory ensures that these environment variables remain set to your specification each time you open a layout editor session.

Changing Settings for Environment Variables in the CIW

Set the variable in the Command Interpreter Window with the command

envSetVal("graphic" "name" type value)

For example:

envSetVal("graphic" "iconsOn" ’boolean t)

or

envSetVal("layout" "name" type value)

For example:

envSetVal("layout" "iconsOn" ’boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "chopShape" ’cyclic "rectangle")
envSetVal("layout" "alignSeparation" ’ 2.0)
envSetVal("layout" "contactColumns" ’int 5)
envSetVal("layout" "filterSizeDrawingStyle" ’string "outlined")

If you set the environment variable by this method prior to opening a cellview window, the next window opened in the session will reflect the change. Any environment variable reset with this method takes effect after any open cellview window is closed and reopened, and in all subsequent windows that are opened in the current session. You must reset the environment variable in the current session to change it. Changes are effective for the current session only.

There are a number of environment variables that are no longer compatible with leSetEnv and leGetEnv. The setting methods for the environment variables are noted in this Appendix under the heading Setting Method, which is included with the description of each environment variable. Cadence recommends that you use only envSetVal and envGetVal to determine the setting of, set, or reset environment variables.

Changing Graphic Environment Variables That Are Cellview Properties

Some graphic environment variables are cellview properties. If you want the changes to the environment variable to be visible in the cellview window immediately, set these variables in the Command Interpreter Window using

window = hiGetCurrentWindow()
window~>environmentVariable = value

For example:

window = hiGetCurrentWindow()
window~>displayStretchHandles = t

This changes the environment variable for the current window only, and you must reset it if you open new windows. The change is effective for the current session only. The setting method for the window environment variables are noted in this Appendix under the heading Setting Method, using the word window, which is included with the description of each environment variable.

Environment Variables in Forms

Some of the environment variables correspond to fields in the layout editor’s forms. The forms corresponding to the environment variables, if any, are noted in this Appendix under the heading GUI Equivalent, which is included with the description of each environment variable. The usual method of changing these options during an editing session is to change the options in the form. If you want to retain these settings for future sessions, save the settings in the CIW – Options – Save Defaults command.

Improving Performance Using Environment Variables

To enhance layout editor performance the following layout environment variables have new default values as of ICOA 5.0.33 and IC 5.0.33. Though performance is data and hardware dependent, these environment variables should reduce the time needed for redrawing the cellview window, panning, and zooming in and out, as compared to IC 4.4.6.

The behavior of filterSize and filterSizeDrawingStyle are changed to display the largest and most essential data, while filtering out smaller shapes, and reducing overall display time.

The filterSize default is changed from 3.0 to 6.0. The behavior of this environment variable is also changed:

  • Shapes: a shape is filtered if two sides of its bounding box are smaller than the filterSize setting. In this case the shape is not displayed.
  • Instances
    • An instance with one side of its bounding box smaller than the filterSize setting displays as an empty rectangle
    • An instance with two sides of its bounding box smaller than the filterSize setting displays according to the modified filterSizeDrawingStyle behavior (see below).

The filterSizeDrawingStyle default is changed from outlined to empty. The behavior of this environment variable is also changed:

  • Shapes: the display of shapes is no longer altered by the filterSizeDrawingStyle setting
  • Instances: with two sides of the bounding box smaller than the filterSize setting display according to the display stop level setting:
    • When instances are above stop level, the instance bounding box displays as a filled rectangle when filterSizeDrawingStyle is set to filled. The instance bounding box displays as a hollow rectangle when filterSizeDrawingStyle is set to outlined. The instance bounding box is not displayed when filterSizeDrawingStyle setting is set to empty.
    • When instances are at stop level the display of instances is no longer altered by the filterSizeDrawingStyle setting. An instance with two sides of its bounding box larger than the filterSize is drawn as an empty rectangle.

The gravityOn default is changed from t to nil. Gravity turned off will speed pointer response time during selection and movement.

The openToStopLevel is changed from nil to t. When set to t all data is loaded to the window stop level (corresponding to the displayStopLevel variable), then rendered. All data is loaded, even data too small to see. When set to nil data loads on demand during rendering. This will increase initial loading time, but usually speeds up subsequent zoom and pan operations.

The dotsOn default is changed from t to nil. Neither the bounding box, nor the diamond origin for dots are displayed when dotsOn is set to nil. Dots are often used for pin shapes. This will shorten overall display time and will decrease screen clutter if you do not need to see dots or dot pins.

The displayStretchHandles default is changed from t to nil. If you do not need to interactively stretch Pcells, this will shorten the overall display time and will decrease screen clutter.

The originMarkersOn default is changed from t to nil. Origin markers of instances will not appear and this will shorten overall display time.

The useTrueBBox is changed from t to nil. Only the instance bounding box displays, which speeds up opening and redrawing times since only the top level data is considered. When set to nil the master bounding box is drawn, or the layer purpose "instance" "drawing" is used. When set to t, one more level of hierarchy is opened and evaluated, which can drastically effect loading and display time.

The following environment variables correspond to fields on the Display Options form under Display Controls: dotsOn (Dot Pins), displayStretchHandles (Stretch Handles), openToStopLevel (Open to Stop Level), originMarkersOn (Instance Origins), and useTrueBBox (Use True BBox). The following environment variables correspond to fields on the Display Options form under Filter: filterSize (Size), and filterSizeDrawingStyle (Style). They can be saved to, loaded from or deleted from a cellview, a library, a technology library or a .cdsenv using this form, however all the settings on this form will also be saved, loaded or deleted.

The new default settings will not take effect if these environment variables are set to other than the default settings as properties of a cellview, a library, a technology library, or are set to values other than the default in the .cdsinit file or the .cdsenv files. The default value will be overwritten by these settings in the order in which they are listed. For example, any override window properties stamped on a cellview will take precedence over a setting in the .cdsenv file.

To find out if the settings of these environment variables are set as a cellview property,

  1. From the cellview window, choose File – Properties.
    The Edit Cellview Properties form appears.
  2. Click the Property radio button.
    All cellview properties are listed in this form.
    You can leave the properties as is, or add. delete, or modify the properties in this form.
  3. Click OK.

To find out if the settings of these environment variables are set as a library property,

  1. From the CIW, window choose Tools – Library Manager
    The Library Manager: <WorkArea> form appears.
  2. In the Library list box, select a library.
  3. Choose Edit – Properties.
    If no properties are assigned to the library, a Library Property Viewer text window appears with the notation “No properties” at the bottom.
    If properties are assigned to the cellview the View Property Editor form appears.
  4. Scroll down to viewProps.
  5. Click EXPAND.
  6. The viewProps properties form appears.
  7. Choose layout or maskLayout and click EXPAND.
  8. The layout properties form appears.
    You can leave the properties as is, or add. delete, or modify the properties in this form.
  9. Click OK.

To find out if the settings of these environment variables are set as a technology library property,

  1. From the CIW window choose Tools – Library Manager
    The Library Manager: <WorkArea> form appears.
  2. In the Library list box, select a technology file.
  3. Choose Edit – Properties.
    If no properties are assigned to the technology library a Library Property Viewer text window appears with the notation “No properties” at the bottom.
    If properties are assigned to the technology library the Library Property Editor form appears.
    You can leave the properties as is, or add. delete, or modify the properties in this form.
  4. Click OK.

To find the settings if environment variables are set in the .cdsinit or .cdsenv,

  1. In a UNIX window, cd to your_install_dir.
  2. Textedit or vi the .cdsinit or .cdsenv
    You can leave the properties as is, or add. delete, or modify the properties in these files.
  3. Save the file, or quit without saving if you do not wish to change the settings.

The gravityOn environment variable corresponds to a field on the Layout Editor Options form under Gravity Controls. It can be can be saved to or loaded from a file, such as the .cdsenv. It will not be found in other locations, and will not be overwritten if it is in your local .cdsenv.

In summary:

Environment Variable Old New Effect

dotsOn

t

nil

Dots are not displayed.

displayStretchHandles

t

nil

Stretch handles are not displayed.

filterSize

3.0

6.0

Objects with one side of less than 6 pixels are not displayed. Instances not at the stop level with two sides of less than 6 pixels are displayed according to the filterSizeDrawingStyle setting.

filterSizeDrawingStyle

outlined

empty

Now used only for instances which are not at the display stop level. When set to empty, instances are not displayed.

gravityOn

t

nil

Gravity is turned off.

openToStopLevel

nil

t

All data is loaded prior to rendering.

originMarkersOn

t

nil

Instance origin markers are not displayed.

useTrueBBox

t

nil

Displays only the instance master bounding box.

xSnapSpacing

ySnapSpacing

yankShape

zoomToFig

abutServerOn

layout abutServerOn boolean { t | nil }

Description

Turns automatic abutment and automatic unabutment on and off.

When set to t, unabutment automatically restores abutted devices when moved apart. This ensures that dropped vias are restored when chained devices are moved apart. It also eliminates errors such as devices with no diffusion overlap on one side.

When set to nil in layout XL, automatic abutment and automatic unabutment are off.

When set to nil in the layout editor, unabutment retains the abutted device configuration even when the device is unabutted.

The default is t.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Editor

Form Field

Abut Server (Layout Editor Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "abutServerOn")
envSetVal("layout" "abutServerOn" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "abutServerOn" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

accessEdgesOn

layout accessEdgesOn boolean { t | nil }
graphic accessEdgesOn boolean { t | nil }

Description

Determines whether you see the access edges of rectangular pins (t) or not. The default value is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Display

Field

Access Edges (Display Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "accessEdgesOn")
envSetVal("layout" "accessEdgesOn" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "accessEdgesOn" 'boolean nil)
envGetVal("graphic" "accessEdgesOn")
envSetVal("graphic" "accessEdgesOn" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("graphic" "accessEdgesOn" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

acuteAnglePath

layout acuteAnglePath boolean { t | nil }

Description

Allows creation of acute angle paths when set to t. Allows creation of paths from 90 degree to 270 degree angles when set to nil. You must set Snap Mode to anyAngle for this environment variable to take effect. The default is t.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – Path

Form Field

Acute Angle (Create Path Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "acuteAnglePath")
envSetVal("layout" "acuteAnglePath" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "acuteAnglePath" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

addDesignLppsToTech 

graphic addDesignLppsToTech boolean { t | nil }

Description

Creates a layer purpose pair (LPP) in the technology file when a shape is present in the design, however, its layer number and purpose number does not correspond to an existing LPP in the technology file. A default packet is used to display shapes on this new LPP.

If layer and purpose names associated with either the layer or purpose numbers, or both are not defined in technology file attached to sub cellviews of the hierarchy, then:

  • Name of the new layer will be LXXX, where XXX is the layer number.
  • Name of the new purpose will be PYYY, where YYY is the purpose number.

The feature is not activated by default and the default value is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("graphic" "addDesignLppsToTech")
envSetVal("graphic" "addDesignLppsToTech" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("graphic" "addDesignLppsToTech" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignApplySpacing

layout alignApplySpacing boolean { t | nil }

Description

Sets the toggle button for the Apply Spacing field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form to on or off. When the value is on (t), the data entry area is enabled. The valid values are t and nil. The default value is nil. To set the value for the data entry area, use the alignSpacingValue environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Form Field

Apply Spacing (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignApplySpacing")
envSetVal("layout" "alignApplySpacing" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "alignApplySpacing" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignDirection

layout alignDirection string { horizontal | vertical }

Description

Sets the Horizontal and Vertical radio buttons for the Align Direction field in the Reference section of the Edit – Advanced – Align form. The valid values are horizontal and vertical. The default is vertical.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Form Field

Align Direction (Align Form)

Examples

envSetVal("layout" "alignDirection" 'string "horizontal")

layout alignLayer string layerPurpose

Description

Enables you to set up the default layer-purpose pair for the Layer list in the Reference and Align Using sections of the Edit – Advanced – Align form. By default, no layer purpose is set up.

alignMethod

layout alignMethod cyclic { top | bottom | left | right | center | origin | upperLeft | upperRight | upperCenter | lowerLeft | lowerRight | lowerCenter | centerLeft | centerRight | centerCenter }

Description

In the Align Using section on the Edit – Advanced – Align form, sets the values in the cyclic Use field for Object or Layer, depending on how the Reference and Align Direction fields are set, as shown in the table below.

When Reference is set to: And Align Direction is set to: And Align Using is set to: The Align Using - Use cyclic list contains: The default value for Use is:

Point

Horizontal or Vertical

Object

Upper Left, Upper Center, Upper Right; Center Left, Center Center, Center Right; Lower Left, Lower Center, Lower Right; Origin

Lower Left

Layer

Upper Left, Upper Center, Upper Right; Center Left, Center Center, Center Right; Lower Left, Lower Center, Lower Right

Lower Left

Object

Horizontal

Object

Top Edge, Bottom Edge, Center; Origin

Center

Layer

Top Edge, Bottom Edge, Center

Center

Vertical

Object

Left Edge, Right Edge, Center; Origin

Center

Layer

Left Edge, Right Edge, Center

Center

Layer

Horizontal

Object

Top Edge, Bottom Edge, Center; Origin

Center

Layer

Vertical

Object

Left Edge, Right Edge, Center; Origin

Center

Horizontal

Layer

Top Edge, Bottom Edge, Center

Center

Vertical

Layer

Left Edge, Right Edge, Center

Center

You can set the Align Using field with the alignUsing environment variable and the Reference field with the alignReference environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Align Using – Object – Use
Align Using – Layer – Use (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignMethod")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "top")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "bottom")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "left")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "right")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "center")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "origin")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "upperLeft")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "upperRight")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "upperCenter")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "lowerLeft")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "lowerRight")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "lowerCenter")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "centerLeft")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "centerRight")
envSetVal("layout" "alignMethod" 'cyclic "centerCenter")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignObjType

layout alignObjType string { instance | row | cluster boundary | any shape | pins }

Description

When the Align Using field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form is set to Object, sets the object type to Instance, Any Shape, Row, Cluster Boundary, Group, or for Layout GXL, Pins. The valid values are: instance, row, cluster boundary, group, any shape and for the floorplanning mode in Layout GXL, pins. You can set the Align Using field with the alignUsing environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Align Using – Object (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignObjType")
envSetVal("layout" "alignObjType" 'cyclic "instance")
envSetVal("layout" "alignObjType" 'cyclic "row")
envSetVal("layout" "alignObjType" 'cyclic "cluster boundary")
envSetVal("layout" "alignObjType" 'cyclic "any shape")
envSetVal("layout" "alignObjType" 'cyclic "group")
envSetVal("layout" "alignObjType" 'cyclic "pins")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignReference

layout alignReference string { point | object | layer }

Description

Sets the Reference field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form to Point, Object, or Layer. The valid values are point, object, or layer. The default is point. For object, instances, rows, cluster boundaries, and groups are supported in layout editor; additionally, pins are supported in Layout EXL.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Reference (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignReference")
envSetVal("layout" "alignReference" 'string "point")
envSetVal("layout" "alignReference" 'string "object")
envSetVal("layout" "alignReference" 'string "layer")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignRefMethod

layout alignRefMethod cyclic { center | top | bottom | left | right | origin }

Description

When the Reference field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form is set to Object or Layer, sets the values in the cyclic Use field, based on whether Align Direction is set to Horizontal or Vertical, as shown in the table below.

When Reference is set to: And Align Direction is set to: The Use Cyclic list contains: The default value is:

Object

Horizontal

Top Edge, Bottom Edge, Center, Origin

Center

Vertical

Left Edge, Right Edge, Center, Origin

Center

Layer

Horizontal

Top Edge, Bottom Edge, Center, Origin

Center

Vertical

Left Edge, Right Edge, Center, Origin

Center

The valid values are: top, bottom, center, left, right, and origin. The default value is center. You can set the Reference field with the alignReference environment variable, and the Align Direction field with the alignDirection environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Reference – Object – Use
Reference – Layer – Use (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod")
envSetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod" 'cyclic "center")
envSetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod" 'cyclic "top")

envSetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod" 'cyclic "bottom")

envSetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod" 'cyclic "left")
envSetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod" 'cyclic "right")
envSetVal("layout" "alignRefMethod" 'cyclic "origin")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

When the Reference field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form is set to Object, sets the object type to Instance, Row, Cluster Boundary, or Group. The valid values are: instance, row, cluster boundary, group, and when in floorplanning mode in Layout GXL, pins. You can set the Reference field with the alignReference environment variable.

The valid values are: alignDirection, horizontal, vertical, orderSelected, instanceName, netName. The default value is alignDirection.

alignSpacingType

layout alignSpacingType string { spacings | pitches }

Description

On the Edit – Advanced – Align form, when the Reference field is set to Point, and the Apply Spacing field is turned on, sets the Between Objects and Pitches radio buttons. The valid values are spacings (for the Between Objects radio button) or pitches. The default value is spacings. You can set the Apply Spacing field with the alignApplySpacing environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Apply Spacing (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignSpacingType")
envSetVal("layout" "alignSpacingType" 'string "spacings")
envSetVal("layout" "alignSpacingType" 'string "pitches")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignSpacingValue

layout alignSpacingValue floating_point_number

Description

When the Apply Spacing field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form is set to on, sets its value. The value must be a integer point number. The default value is 1.0. You can set the Apply Spacing field with the alignApplySpacing environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Apply Spacing (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignSpacingValue")
envSetVal("layout" "alignSpacingValue" 'float 1.0)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignToolBarReferenceObject

layout alignToolBarReferenceObject cyclic { left | top | bottom | right | vertical | horizontal | click }

Description

Selects the reference object from the selection set when using the Align toolbar. The valid values are left, top, bottom, right, vertical, horizontal, or click.

  • left: The leftmost object from the selection set is used as the reference object
  • right: The rightmost object from the selection set is used as the reference object
  • top: The topmost object from the selection set is used as the reference object
  • bottom: The bottommost object from the selection set is used as the reference object
  • horizontal: The object closest to the horizontal center of the selection set bounding box is used as the reference object
  • vertical: The object closest to the vertical center of the selection set bounding box is used as the reference object
  • click: The clicked object is used as the reference object

The default is left.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "left")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "top")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "bottom")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "right")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "vertical")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "horizontal")
envSetVal("layout" "alignToolBarReferenceObject" 'cyclic "click")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignUpdateLabelLayer

layout alignUpdateLabelLayer boolean { t | nil }

Description

Updates the layer of labels to that of the pin. This option can be used when the layers of the pin and label are different.The default value is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Update pin label layer (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignUpdateLabelLayer")
envSetVal("layout" "alignUpdateLabelLayer" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "alignUpdateLabelLayer" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignUsing

layout alignUsing string { object | layer }

Description

Sets the Align Using field on the Edit – Advanced – Align form to Object or Layer. The valid values are object or layer. The default value is object.

  • Setting this variable to object means that target objects of the type specified by the cyclic field will align to the reference point, object, or layer specified in the Reference section of the form.
  • Setting this variable to layer means that target objects on the selected layer will align with the reference point, object, or layer specified in the Reference section of the form.

You can set the Reference field with the alignReference environment variable, the Align Using field with the alignObjType environment variable, and the cyclic field for object type with the alignObjType environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Advanced – Align

Field

Align Using (Align Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignUsing")
envSetVal("layout" "alignUsing" 'string "object")
envSetVal("layout" "alignUsing" 'string "layer")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

alignUsingInstanceDrawingMode 

layout alignUsingInstanceDrawingMode boolean { t | nil }

Description

Aligns the instances based on how they are rendered on the canvas. Instances can be rendered on the canvas as bounding box, true bounding box, PR boundary, or snap boundary. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "alignUsingInstanceDrawingMode")
envSetVal("layout" "alignUsingInstanceDrawingMode" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "alignUsingInstanceDrawingMode" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

anchor

layout anchor cyclic { unknown | left | right }

Description

Adjusts the cellview placement of a chain of instances after the Subtract Finger or Add Finger command is used. The default is left.

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

applyBounce

layout applyBounce boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies if gravity offset (bounce) values are used (t) or not. If applyBounce is set to t, gravityOn is automatically set to t. The default value is nil.

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

askSaveOnReturn

graphic askSaveOnReturn boolean { t | nil }

Description

Determines whether a dialog box appears after the Edit In Place and Descend Edit commands, while in edit mode, and when changes have been made. The dialog box asks if you want to save your changes to a cellview. If set to nil, the dialog box does not appear and the cellview stays open in edit mode. The default is t.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("graphic" "askSaveOnReturn")
envSetVal("graphic" "askSaveOnReturn" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("graphic" "askSaveOnReturn" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoCopyTemplateCellViewList

layout autoCopyTemplateCellViewList string any_cellview

Description

Copies the WSP and row region templates from the specified cellview to the new cellview being opened in the layout window. The copy operation is not performed when opening an existing layout or creating the cellview using database SKILL functions.

The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "autoCopyTemplateCellViewList")
envSetVal("layout" "autoCopyTemplateCellViewList" 'string "(lib1 cell1 layout)")

In the above example, when you open a new cellview, the WSPs and row region specifications from lib1:cell1:layout will be copied to the cellview being created.

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoCircleCreation

layout autoCircleCreation boolean { t | nil }

Description

Sets the Mode field to Click To Place when t, and Draw when nil. The default value is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – Shape – Circle

Field

Mode (Create Circle Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "autoCircleCreation")
envSetVal("layout" "autoCircleCreation" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "autoCircleCreation" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoExtractSaveEnabled

layout autoExtractSaveEnabled boolean { t | nil }

Description

Automatically saves the hierarchical cellviews extracted by the Extract Layout command when the extraction scope is set to Current Cellview and Cellviews in Hierarchy. The default is t.

For more information, see Hierarchical Extraction in the Virtuoso Layout Suite XL User Guide.

GUI Equivalent

Command

In VLS XL,

Connectivity – Update – Extract Layout

Field

Save Extracted Cellviews

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoLoadBindKeys

layout autoLoadBindKeys boolean { t | nil }

Description

Loads the Layout.il file automatically when you run virtuoso. The Layout.il file is searched for in the following locations:

  • <install_dir>/share/cdssetup/dfII/bindkeys/Layout.il
  • ~/.cadence/dfII/bindkeys/<customBindKey>.il
  • ./.cadence/dfII/bindkeys/<customBindKey>.il

The Layout.il file, if found, is loaded from each location in the order specified above. Each Layout.il file is appended to the one that was loaded last. If the Layout.il files contain any overlapping bindkey settings, the bindkey settings defined in the Layout.il file loaded last take effect.

The default value of the environment variable is t. When set to nil, the Layout.il files are not automatically loaded from the above specified paths.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "autoLoadBindKeys")
envSetVal("layout" "autoLoadBindKeys" 'boolean t)

envSetVal("layout" "autoLoadBindKeys" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoModePinSize

layout autoModePinSize boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies whether pin size needs to be set for the rectangular pin created in auto mode (t) or not (nil). The default value is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – Pin – Auto

Field

Pin Size (Create Pin Form)

Examples

envSetVal("layout" "autoModePinSize" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "autoModePinSize" 'boolean nil)

autoModePinSizeFromPath

layout autoModePinSizeFromPath boolean { t | nil }

Description

When set to (t), the shape of the pin is the same as that of underlying path or pathSeg. The default value is nil.

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoPermutePins

layout autoPermutePins boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies whether pins are permuted automatically during manual routing or editing (t) or not (nil). The default is t.

Although autoPermutePins is defined as a layout environment variable, it has no effect in layout editor. It is used only by XL.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Options – Layout XL – Generation tab

Field

Permute pins (Layout XL Options form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "autoPermutePins")
envSetVal("layout" "autoPermutePins" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "autoPermutePins" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoTapShape

layout autoTapShape boolean { t | nil }

Description

Controls whether a design-tap occurs on the first entry point (t) or not (nil), when you create rectangles, polygons, paths, circles, donuts, and ellipses. During the create command, when shape auto tap is on, the current entry layer will seed the form and update attributes of the object you create based on the first point you enter. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Layout Editor

Field

Auto Tap: Shape(Layout Editor Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "autoTapShape")
envSetVal("layout" "autoTapShape" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "autoTapShape" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

autoTapType

layout autoTapType boolean { t | nil }

Description

Controls how the auto tap command behaves. autoTapType is used to set whether attributes of the tapped objects will be used, and whether to switch to a different layer when tapping on an object that is on a different layer than the current layer.

When set to “attributes layer“, both attributes and layers of objects are tapped. When set to “layer “, only layers are tapped. When set to “attributes“, the tap command captures the beginning and ending extensions, the end type, the width.For trls, bends and tapers the tap command captures the bend factor (maximum width before they are chamfered), taper style (linear or exponential), number of points to taper in user units, the bend style (bend chamfer or radial), the width of a chamfered bend in a transmission line as a multiple of its standard width in user units, the number of segments in a radial bend in a transmission line as a function of the number of segments in a 180-degree radial bend, the radius of a radial bend in a transmission line as a multiple of the transmission-line width in user units, the width of the first end of a transmission line bend in user units, the width of the second end of a transmission line bend, and the width of the second end of a transmission line bend in user units.

Default is layer attributes.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Editor

Field

Tap Layer and Tap Attributes (Layout Editor Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "autoTapType")
envSetVal("layout" "autoTapType" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "autoTapType" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

layout autoViaOverrideVariantParameters boolean { t | nil }

Description

Enables the via variant parameter values to be updated in the Single, Stack, and Auto via creation modes. The default value is nil.

layout autoZoomMode cyclic { Pan | Zoom | ZoomToFit }

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

balloonTransparency

layout balloonTransparency int any_integer
graphic balloonTransparency int any_integer

Description

Determines the transparency of the balloon information box. When set to 0, the box is completely transparent. When set to 100, objects behind the box are not visible. The default is 50.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Dynamic Display – Info Balloon tab

Field

Transparency (Dynamic Display Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "balloonTransparency")
envSetVal("layout" "balloonTransparency" 'int 70)
envSetVal("layout" "balloonTransparency" 'int 100)
envGetVal("graphic" "balloonTransparency")
envSetVal("graphic" "balloonTransparency" 'int 25)
envSetVal("graphic" "balloonTransparency" 'int 98)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

bannerFields

layout bannerFields string { X | Y | Mode | Select | SelI | SelO | SelN | Tpt | DRDEnforce | DRDNotify | DRDPost-Edit | CAE | dX | dY | Dist | Cmd }

Description

Enables you to configure the items that appear on the status banner. You can display all, some, or none of the items on the status banner. You can also change the order in which the items appear.

  • You can set the Mode option to full select (F), full select with spine (FS), partial select (P), or partial select with spine (PS).
  • The Select option displays a combination of instances and objects.
  • SelI displays the number of instances selected. In SelI, the last character is the letter I in uppercase, not one. The number following the setting is the number of instances selected.
  • SelO displays the number of objects other than the instances selected. In SelO, the last character is the letter O in uppercase, not zero. The number following the setting is the number of selected objects, other than instances.
  • SelN displays the number of selected nets.
  • Tpt displays (T) if either the Transparent Group icon on the Options toolbar or the Transparent Group option in the Display Options form is turned on.
  • The DRDEnforce, DRDNotify, and DRDPost-Edit options display the status set for DRD modes.
  • The option for constraint aware editing, CAE, is available only in VLS XL and VLS GXL. It can be set to ON or OFF. By default, CAE is OFF.
X, Y, and Mode are coupled. If you set one, the others are automatically set. The same is true for dX, dY and Dist, and Select, SelI and SelO.

By default, this environment variable displays Cmd and SnapMode. Cmd is also available on the Status Toolbar.

The string selections are case sensitive.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "bannerFields")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "X")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "Y")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "Mode")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "Select")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "SelI")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "SelO")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "SelN")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "Tpt")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "DRDEnforce")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "DRDNotify")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "DRDPost-Edit")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "CAE")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "dX")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "dY")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "Dist")
envSetVal("layout" "bannerFields" 'string "Cmd")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

blockageAllowPGNet

layout blockageAllowPGNet boolean { t | nil }

Description

Enables you to place shapes with signal types power and ground within the blockage area. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – P&R Objects – Blockage

Field

Allow PGNet (Create Blockage Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "blockageAllowPGNet")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAllowPGNet" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAllowPGNet" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

blockageAttachOwner

layout blockageAttachOwner string { none | instance | cluster }

Description

Assigns one instance or one cluster as the blockage’s owner, depending upon the type of blockage. In the case of a placement halo blockage, the owner should be an instance or P&R boundary. An owner can have any number of blockages. Use the attach/detach command to add or remove an owner. Cyclical relationships are not allowed. For example, if object A is a parent to object B, then object B cannot be a parent for object A. The default is none.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – P&R Objects – Blockage

Field

Attach to Owner (Create Blockage Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "blockageAttachOwner")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAttachOwner" 'string "none")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAttachOwner" 'string "instance")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAttachOwner" 'string "cluster")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

blockageAttributeMode

layout blockageAttributeMode cyclic { ignoreLPP | useLPP }

Description

Determines the selectability of blockages.

  • If set to ignoreLPP, blockage visibility and selection is controlled by the status of the check box for the corresponding blockage object in the Object pane.
  • If set to useLPP, blockage visibility and selection is controlled by the status of the check box for the corresponding blockage object in the Object pane and the status of the object’s layer-purpose pair attribute in the Layer pane.

The default is ignoreLPP.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "blockageAttributeMode")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAttributeMode" 'cyclic "ignoreLPP")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageAttributeMode" 'cyclic "useLPP")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

blockageCreateMethod

layout blockageCreateMethod string { manual | automatic }

Description

Sets the method used to create a blockage. Manual requires that you enter points to define the blockage. Automatic derives points from objects you select, then creates the blockage from these points. The default is manual.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – P&R Objects – Blockage

Field

Create Method (Create Blockage Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "blockageCreateMethod")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageCreateMethod" 'string "manual")
envSetVal("layout" "blockageCreateMethod" 'string "automatic")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

envSetVal("layout" "blockageDerivePoints" 'string "Instance bBox")

bondPadLPP

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

boundarySnappingLayer

layout boundarySnappingLayer string "layerName1 layerName2"

Description

Overrides the grid for PR boundary snapping. If this environment variable is specified, the , PR boundary snaps to the active grids whose snapping layers are specified in this environment variable. If this environment variable is not specified, snapping is done based on the grids specified in boundarySnapXGrids and boundarySnapYGrids environment variables. In case boundarySnapXGrids and boundarySnapYGrids environment variables are not specified, snapping is done to the least common multiple of all active grids.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "boundarySnappingLayer")
envSetVal("layout" "boundarySnappingLayer" 'string "M1WSP")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

boundarySnapXGrids

layout boundarySnapXGrids string "grid"

Description

Snaps the PR boundary to the specified grid(s) in the X direction.

The grids specified through this environment variable need not be active global grids.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "boundarySnapXGrids")
envSetVal("layout" "boundarySnapXGrids" 'string "M1WSP")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

boundarySnapYGrids

layout boundarySnapYGrids string "grid"

Description

Snaps the PR boundary to the specified grid(s) in the Y direction.

The grids specified through this environment variable need not be active global grids.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "boundarySnapYGrids")
envSetVal("layout" "boundarySnapYGrids" 'string "M2WSP M4WSP")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

chainMode

layout chainMode cyclic { unknown | all | selected | selectLeft | selectRight }

Description

Determines which instances in a chain of instances will move, copy, stretch or delete. All moves, copies, stretches, or deletes all instances in a chain together. selected moves, copies, stretches, or deletes only selected instances irrespective of the chain contents. selectLeft moves, copies, stretches, or deletes the instance selected and all instances to the left of the selected instance in the chain. selectRight moves, copies, stretches, or deletes the instance selected and all instances to the right of the selected instance in the chain. The default is selected.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Move, Edit – Copy, Edit – Stretch, Edit – Delete

Field

Chain Mode (Move Form, Copy Form, Stretch Form, Delete Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "chainMode")
envSetVal("layout" "chainMode" 'cyclic "unknown")
envSetVal("layout" "chainMode" 'cyclic "all")
envSetVal("layout" "chainMode" 'cyclic "selected")
envSetVal("layout" "chainMode" 'cyclic "selectLeft")
envSetVal("layout" "chainMode" 'cyclic "selectRight")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

checkAllSPGridsEnclosures

layout checkAllSPGridsEnclosures boolean {t | nil}

Description

During snapping in detailed mode, if this environment variable is set to t, Virtuoso searches all enclosures to locate the one that centers the shape on the tracks.

The default value is t.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "checkAllSPGridsEnclosures")
envSetVal("layout" "checkAllSPGridsEnclosures" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "checkAllSPGridsEnclosures" 'boolean nil)

When the checkAllSPGridsEnclosures environment variable is set to t, all enclosures values (0.009, 0.01, and 0.012) are evaluated one by one. When the enviroment variable is set to nil, only the first enclosure vlalue (0.009) is evaluated.

snapPatternDefs(
(GPG94        ("PPitch" "poly94")
     'step                 0.094
     'stepDirection        "horizontal"
     'snappingLayers       (('layer "Poly" 'enclosures (0.009 0.01 0.012) 'purposes ("drawing" "dummy")))
     'type                 "local"
  )
)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

checkHalfWidthPathSeg

layout checkHalfWidthPathSeg cyclic { off | notify | enforce | never }

Description

Provides control for checking the width of a path segment with respect to the width of the path. This environment variable applies to commands used for creating and editing paths, including ROD MPPs and their subpaths.

When off, which is the default value, no warning is issued when you create or edit a path that has a segment length less than half the path width, except if it is the first or last segment. If you create or edit the first or last segment of the path with a length less than half the path width, the endStyle extension is used to determine the segment length. If the environment variable is set to notify and you attempt to create or edit a path that has a segment length less than half the path width, a warning dialog box appears. If you confirm to create or edit the short segment as an intended action, the path is created or updated, else the last attempted edit is ignored. If set to enforce, you will not be allowed to create a path segment with length less than half the path width.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Editor

Field

Half Width Check (Layout Editor Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "checkHalfWidthPathSeg")
envSetVal("layout" "checkHalfWidthPathSeg" 'cyclic "off")
envSetVal("layout" "checkHalfWidthPathSeg" 'cyclic "notify")
envSetVal("layout" "checkHalfWidthPathSeg" 'cyclic "enforce")
envSetVal("layout" "checkHalfWidthPathSeg" 'cyclic "never")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

checkLargeCoordinates

layout checkLargeCoordinates boolean {t | nil}

Description

Provides control for checking for large coordinates during the copy operation. If set to t, the Copy command does not allow objects to go out of the INT_MAX boundary and hence does not distort the copied image. On 64-bit system, INT_MAX = 2147483647.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Editor

Field

Check Large Coordinates (Layout Editor Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "checkLargeCoordinates")
envSetVal("layout" "checkLargeCoordinates" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "checkLargeCoordinates" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

chopArray

layout chopArray boolean { t | nil }

Description

Enables you to specify whether or not to chop an array of instances (mosaic). If set to t, the array of instances is allowed to be chopped based on the shape (line, rectangle, polygon) selected for chopping. If set to nil, the array of instances is not chopped. The default value of the variable is t.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Basic – Chop

Field

Chop array (Chop Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "chopArray")
envSetVal("layout" "chopArray" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "chopArray" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

clusterBoundaryAspectRatio

layout clusterBoundaryAspectRatio floating_point_number

Description

In Virtuoso XL, sets the aspect ratio of the cluster boundary during auto-creation. Aspect Ratio W/L is the width-to-length ratio of the cluster boundary. For example, a value of 1 specifies a square boundary, 2 specifies a boundary twice as high as it is long, and .5 specifies a boundary half as wide as it is long.The default is 1.0.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – P&R Objects – Cluster Boundary

Field

Aspect Ratio (W/H) (Create Cluster Boundary Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "clusterBoundaryAspectRatio")
envSetVal("layout" "clusterBoundaryAspectRatio" 'float 2.0)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

clusterBoundaryUtilization

layout clusterBoundaryUtilization floating_point_number

Description

In Virtuoso XL, specifies the percentage of area within the cluster boundary that you want to fill. The default is 80.0.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – P&R Objects – Cluster Boundary

Field

Utilization % (Create Cluster Boundary Form)

Examples

envSetVal("layout" "clusterBoundaryUtilization" 'float 90.0)

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

convertEachInstanceIntoMosaic

layout convertEachInstanceIntoMosaic 'boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies the mode for the Convert to Mosaic command.

  • When set to t, the command converts the currently selected instances into the equivalent number of individual mosaics.
  • When set to nil, the command converts the currently selected instances into a single mosaic.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Convert – To Mosaic

Fields

Convert Instances into Mosaics (t)

Convert Instances into Single Mosaic (nil)

Examples

copyResetRowCol

layout copyResetRowCol boolean { t | nil }

Description

Sets the default location for the Copy form’s Rows and Columns fields each time you repeat the Copy command. When t, the location is set to the .cdsenv file. When nil, the last value entered in the form fields is retained.

createInstResetCDF

layout createInstResetCDF boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies whether the Create Instance command retains the current effective CDF values for a component when the same component is placed at a later time. If set to t, the editor CDF resets the CDF values to their default settings when you start the Create Instance command. The default is nil.

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

createPinPathSpineAware

layout createPinPathSpineAware boolean { t | nil }

Description

Determines whether pins created in the Single mode are path spine aware.

  • When set to t, a single merged pin is created on the highest metal layer shape island. A metal layer shape island is made of overlapping shapes that belong to the same layer and net.
  • When set to nil, a single pin is created on the highest metal layer shape island.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "createPinPathSpineAware")
envSetVal("layout" "createPinPathSpineAware" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "createPinPathSpineAware" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

Creating Pins Automatically

createPinSchematicAware

layout createPinSchematicAware boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies whether pin creation must be schematic aware. When set to t, the tool uses its I/O Type and Signal Type values from corresponding schematic reference. When set to nil or if the corresponding schematic reference is not found, the values specified in the Create Pin form are used.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Create – Pin

Field

Schematic Aware (Create Pin Form)

 
envGetVal("layout" "createPinSchematicAware")
envSetVal("layout" "createPinSchematicAware" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "createPinSchematicAware" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

createRectilinearBoundary

layout createRectilinearBoundary boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies that a rectilinear PR boundary is created by merging the PR boundary of the overlapping instances in the selection set. In case, there is no overlap between the selected instances, a rectangular PR boundary is created instead of rectilinear PR boundary. If this environment variable is set to nil, a rectangular PR boundary is created from the bounding box of the selection set.The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "createRectilinearBoundary")
envSetVal("layout" "createRectilinearBoundary" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "createRectilinearBoundary" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

createViaAlwaysUsesDefinedCalcMode

layout createViaAlwaysUsesDefinedCalcMode boolean { t | nil}

Description

Enables the via engine to use the calculation mode defined in the Layout Editor Options form for creating vias. If the environment variable is set to nil, the via engine uses pre-defined values for creating vias in Single, Stack, or Auto mode. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "createViaAlwaysUsesDefinedCalcMode")
envSetVal("layout" "createViaAlwaysUsesDefinedCalcMode" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "createViaAlwaysUsesDefinedCalcMode" 'boolean nil)

descendPromptForView

layout descendPromptForView boolean { t | nil }

Description

Determines whether to open the Descend (view name) form when you click an instance. In the Descend (view name) form, you can choose a different view to open. If there is only one view of the master cell, Descend does not prompt you for a view name. If set to nil, the default view is the view name of the selected object. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit – Hierarchy – Descend Read

Field

Prompt For View Name (Descend Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "descendPromptForView")

envSetVal("graphic" "dimGridLines" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("graphic" "dimGridLines" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

dimmingAutoEnabled

Determines whether or not to automatically dim the design when you select an object or when the design contains highlight sets or probes.

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

dimmingIntensity 

layout dimmingIntensity int integer_number
graphic dimmingIntensity int integer_number

Description

Determines the luminosity of the dimmed objects. When set to 0 nothing is dimmed. When set to 100 dimmed objects are not visible. The default is 50.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Display

Field

Dim Intensity (Display Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "dimmingIntensity")
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingIntensity" 'int 70)
envGetVal("graphic" "dimmingIntensity")
envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingIntensity" 'int 70)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

dimmingOn 

layout dimmingOn boolean { t | nil }
graphic dimmingOn boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies whether you can change the luminosity of the objects in the cellview. The default value is nil.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Display

Field

Enable Dimming (Display Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "dimmingOn")
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingOn" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingOn" 'boolean nil)

envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingOn" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingOn" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

dimmingScope 

layout dimmingScope string { none | all | outside | eipSurround }
graphic dimmingScope string { none | all | outside | eipSurround }

Description

Determines how objects in the cellview are dimmed.

  • none: no dimming is applied.
  • outside: dims everything but the instance, figure group, or any object you are editing in place.
  • all: the design is completely dimmed as soon as you select this option. If you select an object and the dimming is set to 100, only the selection box is displayed.
  • eipSurround: dims all the objects surrounding the EIP hierarchy.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Display

Field

Scope (Display Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "dimmingScope")
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingScope" 'string "none")
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingScope" 'string "all")
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingScope" 'string "outside")
envSetVal("layout" "dimmingScope" 'string "eipSurround")
envGetVal("graphic" "dimmingScope")
envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingScope" 'string "none")
envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingScope" 'string "all")
envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingScope" 'string "outside")
envSetVal("graphic" "dimmingScope" 'string "eipSurround")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

disableLayerFuncSnapToMfgGrid

layout disableLayerFuncSnapToMfggrid boolean { t | nil }

Description

By default, the leLayer*, leMergeShapes and leSizeShape functions do not put data on grid. These functions are effected by the environment variable disableLayerFuncSnapToMfgGrid. To force the le functions (and the corresponding functions from the menus) to put data results on grid, set the disableLayerFuncSnapToMfgGrid function to nil.

The dbLayer* functions do not put date results back onto the manufacturing grid and are unaffected by the disableLayerFuncSnapToMfgGrid environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "disableLayerFuncSnapToMfggrid")
envSetVal("layout" "disableLayerFuncSnapToMfggrid" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "disableLayerFuncSnapToMfggrid" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

discardCVEditOnWindowClose 

graphic discardCVEditOnWindowClose boolean { t | nil }

Description

Controls whether the changes done in the cellview are saved when you click No in the Save Changes dialog box. The default is t. When set to nil, the changes done in the cellview are preserved in the memory when you click No in the Save Changes dialog box.

displaySchDashText

graphic displaySchDashText boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies how to display text or labels. When set to t, text or labels are displayed as small lines when the schematic or symbol is zoomed out. When set to nil, the text or labels always display, even when the window is zoomed out. The default is nil.

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

displayViaShapes

layout displayViaShapes boolean { t | nil }
graphic displayViaShapes boolean { t | nil }

Description

Displays via attributes. When Via Shapes is set to nil (the default), vias are displayed as the bounding box of each via. When set to t via attributes are graphically displayed, resulting in detailed images. For large designs, setting via shapes to t will increase the amount of time it takes to render a design.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Display

Field

Via Shapes (Display Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "displayViaShapes")
envSetVal("layout" "displayViaShapes" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "displayViaShapes" 'boolean nil)
envGetVal("graphic" "displayViaShapes")
envSetVal("graphic" "displayViaShapes" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("graphic" "displayViaShapes" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

drawEngine

graphic drawEngine int { 0 | 1 }

Description

Determines whether or not all data in a cellview is rendered. If 0, all data is drawn including that which will be obscured by data on overlying layers. If 1, only data which will ultimately be viewable is drawn. This function works best on large designs with closely placed data. It is slower on small designs, as the pruning of overlapping data takes longer than redrawing a small amount of data. The default is 0.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("graphic" "drawEngine")
envSetVal("graphic" "drawEngine" 'int 1)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

drawGridOn

layout drawGridOn boolean { t | nil }

drfPath

grahic drfPath string path

Description

Specifies the path to the Display Resource File. The default is none.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "drfPath")

envSetVal("layout" "drfPath" 'string "~/.display.drf")

Related Topics

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

editInstanceBoundaryMode

layout editInstanceBoundaryMode cyclic { BBox | prBoundary | snapBoundary }

Description

Specifies whether the Flip and Rotate commands use the instance bounding box (BBox), the place and route boundary (prBoundary), or the snap boundary (snapBoundary) as the instance border when operating on instances and mosaics.

For example, if you have a standard cell with a large label that extends well beyond the PR boundary, the bounding box of that cell will be much larger than its place and route boundary. Set this environment variable to prBoundary to have Flip and Rotate ignore the bounding box and consider only the PR boundary when operating on the cell.

The default is BBox. If you set this environment variable to prBoundary or snapBoundary and the instance or mosaic does not have the corresponding boundary, then BBox is used instead.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Options – Editor

Field

Instance Editing Mode (Layout Editor Options Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "editInstanceBoundaryMode")
envSetVal("layout" "editInstanceBoundaryMode" 'cyclic "BBox")
envSetVal("layout" "editInstanceBoundaryMode" 'cyclic "prBoundary")
envSetVal("layout" "editInstanceBoundaryMode" 'cyclic "snapBoundary")

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

enableCopyAndPaste 

layout enableCopyAndPaste boolean { t | nil }

Description

When set to on (t), in the Copy command, the selected objects and the reference point are automatically stored in the buffer after the reference point for the copy command has been specified. You can use the Paste command to paste the objects stored in the buffer. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "enableCopyAndPaste")
envSetVal("layout" "enableCopyAndPaste" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "enableCopyAndPaste" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

enableEIPEnhancements 

layout enableEIPEnhancements boolean { t | nil }

Description

When set to on (t), the following edit in place enhancements are available:

  • When editing in place in a hierarchy, clicking a shape at the top level performs return to top.
  • For figures inside a group inside an instance, by default, the EIP target is the figure (descend into instance and descend into the group). You can use the Space key to cycle through the instance and group or just the instance.
  • When you return from instance and group, you can specify the options in the Group Return form.

The default is t.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "enableEIPEnhancements")
envSetVal("layout" "enableEIPEnhancements" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "enableEIPEnhancements" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

enableSyncCloneEditing

layout enableSyncCloneEditing cyclic { Ask | Never | Always }

Description

Controls the display of the Edit Synchronous Clone form.

  • Ask: The Edit Synchronous Clone form is displayed when you edit a clone.
  • Never: The Edit Synchronous Clone form is not displayed when you edit a clone and the clone is not edited.
  • Always: The Edit Synchronous Clone form is not displayed when you edit a clone and the clone is edited.

The default is Ask.

GUI Equivalent

Command

Edit Synchronous Clone

Field

Apply same action to all other clones (Edit Synchronous Clone Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "enableSyncCloneEditing")
envSetVal("layout" "enableSyncCloneEditing" 'cyclic "Ask")
envSetVal("layout" "enableSyncCloneEditing" 'cyclic "Never")
envSetVal("layout" "enableSyncCloneEditing" 'cyclic "Always")

Related Topics

extendPathLengthCheck

layout extendPathLengthCheck boolean { t | nil }

Description

When set to on (t), paths or path segments created with a segment of less than 1/2 the path width is checked and a warning is issued. When set to off (nil), no check is made and no warning is issued. The default is nil.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extendPathLengthCheck")
envSetVal("layout" "extendPathLengthCheck" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extendPathLengthCheck" 'boolean nil)

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

extractAfterGenerateAll

layout extractAfterGenerateAll boolean { t | nil }

Description

Runs connectivity extraction as part of the Generate All From Source command. Switch on this environment variable to see the incomplete nets in the design immediately after layout generation has run.

This option has no effect on either the Generate Selected From Source or Update Components And Nets commands. Connectivity extraction for these commands is controlled using the extractEnabled environment variable.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Connectivity – Generate – All From Source – Generate

Field

Extract Connectivity after Generation(Generate Layout Form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractAfterGenerateAll")

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

extractCellviewOpenViolationLimit

layout extractCellviewOpenViolationLimit int integer

Description

Specifies the maximum number of open violations generated by the extractor for a particular cellview. Limiting the number can improve performance when you are editing either a large design or a net with a large number of instance terminals and terminals in an unrouted design.

The default is 5000.

This environment variable is considered only when extractEnabled and extractVerifyOpenViolations are switched on.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Options – Layout XL – Connectivity – Limits

Field

Maximum number of opens: By cellview

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractCellviewOpenViolationLimit")

extractConsiderAllCutLayersInVias

layout extractConsiderAllCutLayersInVias boolean { t | nil }

Description

Considers all cut layers inside vias as extractable, even if the cut layer is not listed in the validLayers constraint.

The default is t.

Cadence recommends that you list all the extractable layers in the validLayers constraint. If there are no extractable layers defined in the constraint group, Layout XL is launched with the connectivity extractor disabled.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractConsiderAllCutLayersInVias")
envSetVal("layout" "extractConsiderAllCutLayersInVias" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extractConsiderAllCutLayersInVias" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

validLayers

viaDef

extractEnabled

layout extractEnabled boolean { t | nil }

Description

Enables incremental connectivity extraction during interactive editing, meaning that the connectivity model is updated automatically as you edit your design.

You specify how the extraction is performed and what is displayed in the layout window using the following environment variables. Indentation is used to show the dependencies between the environment variables.

  • extractStopLevel
  • extractVerifyMustConnectMarkers
  • extractVerifyOpenViolations
    • extractCellviewOpenViolationLimit
    • extractNetOpenViolationLimit
    • extractVerifyUnimplementedInstTerms
  • extractVerifyWeakMarkers

The default is t.

When set to nil, the connectivity model is not updated during interactive editing and no new short or open violation markers are generated in the layout window.

When the incremental extractor is switched off, you can still run connectivity extraction at any time using the Connectivity – Extract Layout command.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Options – Layout XL – Connectivity – Controls

Field

Update connectivity information when design is modified

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractEnabled")
envSetVal("layout" "extractEnabled" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extractEnabled" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

Connectivity Extraction

extractEnableVirtualConnections

layout extractEnableVirtualConnections boolean { t | nil}

Description

Enables connectivity extraction from virtual-connect labels that are either attached or stamped to a shape.

The default is t, which means that sets of physically connected shapes that are on the same net and tagged by a label comprising the net name followed by a virtual-connect separator are considered as connected.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Options – Layout XL – Connectivity – Controls

Field

Enable virtual connections

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractEnableVirtualConnections")
envSetVal("layout" "extractEnableVirtualConnections" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extractEnableVirtualConnections" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

Layout XL Options Form

extractRunOnInit

layout extractRunOnInit boolean { t | nil }

Description

Runs connectivity extraction automatically when you launch Layout XL (or GXL) from Layout L.

The default is nil, meaning that connectivity extraction is not run automatically when you launch either application.

Enabling this environment variable means that connectivity extraction is run even if it not required and adversely impacts the performance of Layout XL during initialization. Cadence recommends that you do not enable this environment variable by default, but that you use the Connectivity – Extract Layout command when you know it is required.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractRunOnInit")
envSetVal("layout" "extractRunOnInit" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extractRunOnInit" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

extractStopLevel

layout extractStopLevel int { 0 | 1 | 2 | ... | 32 }

Description

Specifies how much of the design hierarchy the extractor considers when extracting the design. The default is 0, which means that the extractor extracts only

  • Top-level objects; that is, shapes, vias, and instances used to implement pins
  • Instance pins of top-level instances. These instance pins represent the interface of top-level instances to the lower levels in the design and are themselves considered to be at the top level.

Increasing the extractStopLevel increases the extractor’s visibility of the shapes inside the hierarchy. For example,

extractStopLevel Means...

1

extractStopLevel 0 + objects at level 1 + instance pins at level 2

2

extractStopLevel 1 + objects at level 2 + instance pins at level 3

Whatever the extractStopLevel, the extractor only ever extracts the top level; i.e., it only ever changes the connectivity of objects or creates markers at the top level.

GUI Equivalent

Command

(In Layout XL) Options – Layout XL – Connectivity – Controls

Field

Extract connectivity to level (Layout XL Options form)

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractStopLevel")
envSetVal("layout" "extractStopLevel" 'int 20)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

extractVerifyAnalogSigType

layout extractVerifyAnalogSigType boolean { t | nil }

Description

Creates markers for nets that have their Signal type set as Analog. These markers can be viewed in the Annotation Browser.

The default value is t.

GUI Equivalent

Command:

Connectivity – Connectivity –

Annotations

Field:

Signal types – Analog

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractVerifyAnalogSigType")
envSetVal("layout" "extractVerifyAnalogSigType" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extractVerifyAnalogSigType" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

extractVerifyBigMPP

layout extractVerifyBigMPP boolean { t | nil }

Description

Specifies that the connectivity extractor is to extract through large multipart paths. A large multipart path is one that contains more than 1000 elements. These are typically used to implement physical-only structures such as isolation rings, and therefore do not need to be extracted.

The default is nil, which means that the extractor ignores them.

Setting this environment variable to t can adversely affect the performance of the extractor.

GUI Equivalent

None

Examples

envGetVal("layout" "extractVerifyBigMPP")
envSetVal("layout" "extractVerifyBigMPP" 'boolean t)
envSetVal("layout" "extractVerifyBigMPP" 'boolean nil)

Related Topics

List of Layout Editor Environment Variables

layout extractVerifyClockSigType boolean { t | nil }

Creates markers for nets that have their Signal type set as Clock. These markers can be viewed in the Annotation Browser.

The default value is t.

Signal types – Clock
